A Summary of the 1954 Study
of New York Television
An analysis of a co plete week of metropolitan New York's commercial television
has been mad© by the Purdue Opinion Pane for the Ni ionaJ Association of Educational
Bread casters. This study* the fourth In an annual series begun in 1951 by the NAEB*
was concerned with the content of television programs monitored bet aen January 25
ari 31 by the Purdue Opinion Panel,
More than 662 hours of television were viewed by monitoring teams during
he study week. Some of the resulting facts confirm findings from previous years*
/hile others bring new TV trends to light. Entertainment continues to make up the
bulk of TV programs wrth 77*. 7 per cent of all air time . Among entertainment pro¬
grams* drama alone accounts for more than 46 per cent of all broadcast time. Some
slight changes in programming practices have been found A larger proportion of
air time is given to comedy drama and less to crime and domestic or "soap opera"
drama. General information programs covering such to ics as cooking* arts* crafts
and 5>imilar topics are on the decrease In general* however* the analysts conclude
that programming practises in commercial New York television have stabilized,
